structured_info.title_cn: 混合高速公路交通中的自动驾驶车辆：容量利用、影响及政策启示
structured_info.title_en: Autonomous vehicles in mixed motorway traffic: capacity utilisation, impact and policy implications
structured_info.abstract: In upcoming years, the introduction of autonomous vehicles (AVs) will reshape the transport system. The transition from a regular to an autonomous transport system, however, will take place over many years and lead to a long period with a mixed driving environment where AVs and regular vehicles (RVs) operate side by side. The purpose of this study is to investigate how the utilisation of the road capacity degrades as a function of heterogeneity in congested motorways. The analysis is based on a dedicated traffic simulator, which enables the investigation of complex dynamic spillback from congestion while allowing for different degrees of heterogeneity. The representation of autonomous vehicles is based on a modified intelligent driver model (IIDM) presented by Treiber et al. (Phys Rev E 62(2):1805 1824, 2000) and Treiber and Kesting (Traffic flow dynamics, Springer, Heidelberg, 2013), while the behaviour of drivers of RVs relies on a stochastic version of the IIDM. Three main conclusions stand out. Firstly, it is shown that in an idealised environment in which AVs operate alone, a substantially improved capacity utilisation can be attained. Secondly, when drivers of RVs are mixed with AVs, capacity utilisation degrades very fast as a function of the share of RVs. Thirdly, it is shown that the improved capacity utilisation of AVs comes in the form of reduced travel time and increased throughput, with indications that travel time reductions are the most important.
structured_info.methodology: The study uses a dedicated traffic simulator based on the Improved Intelligent Driver Model (IIDM) to simulate mixed traffic scenarios with varying shares of autonomous and regular vehicles. The simulation framework includes demand, car-following, overtaking, and performance indicators modules.
structured_info.conclusion: The study concludes that AVs significantly improve road capacity utilization when operating alone, but this benefit degrades rapidly when mixed with regular vehicles. Dedicated AV lanes are recommended to maximize the benefits of AVs, as they can triple consumer surplus compared to mixed traffic scenarios.

analysis.Overview: The paper investigates the impact of autonomous vehicles (AVs) on road capacity utilization in mixed traffic scenarios using a traffic simulation model based on the Improved Intelligent Driver Model (IIDM).
Background_and_Motivation: The introduction of AVs is expected to alleviate congestion, but the transition period will involve mixed traffic environments.
The study aims to quantify how road capacity utilization degrades with increasing heterogeneity due to mixed AV and regular vehicle (RV) traffic.
The authors highlight the necessity of understanding mixed traffic dynamics for long-term infrastructure planning.
The research problem is linked to broader challenges of traffic management and infrastructure planning.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering and traffic simulation fields.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts: Autonomous Vehicles (AVs), Regular Vehicles (RVs), Improved Intelligent Driver Model (IIDM).
AVs are modeled as homogeneous with optimal speed control, while RVs are heterogeneous with stochastic driving behaviors.
Key assumptions include collision-free driving and Markov properties for vehicle interactions.
The paper contributes by quantifying the 'cost' of heterogeneity in mixed traffic and advocating for dedicated AV lanes.
Methodology: The core method is a microsimulation framework based on the IIDM, extended to include stochastic parameters for RVs.
The methodology is novel in its application to mixed traffic and its focus on heterogeneity's impact on capacity.
Data sources include realistic demand profiles for a Copenhagen motorway, with parameters calibrated from literature.
Experimental design includes varying AV penetration rates and measuring performance indicators like travel time and throughput.
The research follows the theoretical paradigm of traffic flow dynamics and microsimulation.
Results: Key results show that AVs alone can significantly improve capacity utilization, but mixed traffic degrades performance rapidly.
Results are reliable and stable, supported by sensitivity analyses and validation against real-world data.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The argument structure begins with the problem statement, followed by methodology, results, and policy implications.
Key steps include modeling AVs and RVs, simulating mixed traffic, and analyzing performance indicators.
Strengths include comprehensive simulation and sensitivity analysis; weaknesses include simplified overtaking models.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths: Detailed simulation framework, clear policy implications, robust sensitivity analysis.
Limitations: Simplified overtaking models, idealized traffic conditions.
Theoretical constraints include assumptions about homogeneous AV behavior and Markov properties.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper positions itself within the discourse on AVs and traffic management, citing relevant literature.
Terminology is technical but accessible, with a focus on empirical results.
Citations build authority by referencing foundational works in traffic simulation.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Main conclusions: AVs improve capacity utilization, but mixed traffic reduces benefits; dedicated lanes are recommended.
Future research should explore more complex traffic scenarios and real-world implementations.
